Posts.Content: Wow, talk about an unexpected event! Your case is very interesting to me. My brothers pathology was a G6 pre and post-surgery. He is not compliant with PSA testing and bases his behavior on what he sites as very unlikely to progress based on the science. I have included a link which actually is supportive of Active Surveillance. However the first two bullet points have significant relevance to your situation. If your pathology is accurate it would place you in an extremely uncommon position. One possibility could be that you are one of the very rare people that have biological grade progression, Gleason 3 cells giving rise to Gleason 4 or 5 progeny. As noted in the attached document this can occur overtime but is very uncommon. Did you have a second opinion on your pathology? I did not have an official second opinion (4+3-7) but it would be a consideration given the situation that you find yourself in. Good Luck, Very interesting, please keep updating http://prostatecancerinfolink.net/20...lated-factors/
Posts.Title: Probable reoccurence following RP 4 1/2 yers ago.

Posts.Title: Probable reoccurence following RP 4 1/2 yers ago.

Posts.Content: Water, As suggested it is important to follow-up. A local urologist can get to the answer quickly. If you do end up with cancer and needing the services of a cancer institute I always suggest using a NCI (http://www.cancer.gov/research/nci-r...r-centers/find) this designation is not something just handed out. Vanderbilt-Ingram (http://www.cancer.gov/research/nci-r...nderbiltingram) would be a good place. If you are way east in TN perhaps St. Louis would be a consideration at Siteman, (http://www.cancer.gov/research/nci-r...hingtonsiteman). I had all of my care with Siteman and I am very pleased. Hopefully you don't need any cancer care but with the reported PSA result one must be prepared. BTW my father also passed with advanced prostate cancer. Out of 3 boys two of us were diagnosed with prostate cancer, my other brother who is the spitt'n image of my dad has had multiple biopsies and has been negative each time. Please keep us posted. SN

Posts.Content: I do not have any knowledge of what type of equipment is available for radiotherapy in Estonia. I am sure that you have well trained and caring providers but state of the art equipment is very important. Here in the States I encourage men to go to a center of excellence for radiotherapy, these locations have the most modern equipment available. But even in that environment some unpleasant side effects can develop (radiation is a powerful thing). Hopefully medication management can improve your father’s condition. My best to you and your father.

Posts.Content: Welcome and good luck. Not always, but some VA specialist are frequently associated with an accidemic center. If one is in your area you could check for an affiliation with this doc and could perhaps glean addition info. However it sounds like your options are limited. My best
